comment._content: the host must have been a dancing fool......

comment._content: An orchestra of two. How minimalist.

comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: Looks like it is quite literally "wall paper."

comment.author: 23224989@N07
comment._content:
Title:  The accused
Is this a joyful occasion?  Seems pretty tense to me!

comment.author: 23393335@N06
comment._content: The 'host' might also be the 'caller' the one who cued the dancers to the next steps [swing your partner, do-si-do, allamende left, grand right and left, etc.]

comment.author: 27056077@N00
comment._content: This was before they invented wall paper glue.

comment.author: 10305914@N08
comment._content: Square dancing is hard work!  If the caller is good, you are constantly on the move.  Dancin' up a sweat is normal.

comment.author: 24530173@N07
comment._content: I think the paper was their way of trying to insulate the house.  I remember my grandfather, who was raised in Oklahoma, telling me that people used to put paper or cardboard on the walls for that purpose.  Also, it's likely that this was during the middle of summer-- Oklahoma summers can get pretty brutal! :P

comment.author: 15614078@N06
comment._content:
It's funny how something can be 70 years out of place and be totally familiar.

I've played guitar for square-dance bands off and on for 15 or so years and we still play house dances that, except for the superficial details (clothing, etc.) look just like that.

comment.author: 48889055628@N01
comment._content: Looking at the other pics of this dance, it seems like a very confined space for dancing. Not much ventilation either. I bet it was pretty funky smelling in there after the folks had been dancing awhile, but you'd get used to it.
